recordings.file-name: XC564759-crystallised song from a Lesser Whitethroat near Cork city 1st June 2020_HH_stereo_1.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Two different song strophe types from a presumed male Lesser Whitethroat in an area of potential breeding habitat. This bird was within 5km of the above location, the precise location is withheld, at least for now, in case the bird is part of a breeding pair. No deliberate playback was attempted, so as not to disturb the bird, and it was singing and showing occasionally anyway, but it may have reacted to my brief listen back to a recording of it from a few minutes previously to see how it came out. I stopped that listen immediately in case that this had prompted a reaction.

  Interestingly, as well as the more typical 'rattle' strophes, this bird also habitually threw in another song strophe type reminiscent of a Coal Tit, perhaps, and which could be dismissed as 'just a tit' if heard out of context from an unseen bird. Whether this is innate, and part of the normal 'vocabulary' of the species, or actual mimicry of a Coal Tit, I don't know. 

  Lesser Whitethroat is a scarce passage migrant in Ireland, mainly being found on headlands and islands, and is commoner in autumn than spring, though always a good find anywhere. Sporadic breeding records have been proven, and the incidence of singing birds in spring seems to be increasing, but, of course, the twin combination of low observer density and reduced effort away from the hotspots could lead to under-recording of the true picture. In this case, I may not have walked by the area in which the bird is holding territory were it not for travel restrictions due to COVID-19, and certainly wouldn't have found it had it not sang. It effectively didn't show at all when found on 30th May, bar for one flight view.

   Notch filter applied below 250Hz, fade in and out applied also.

recordings.file-name: XC564397-crystallised song from a Lesser Whitethroat near Cork city 1st June 2020_HH_stereo_9.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Two different song strophe types from a presumed male Lesser Whitethroat in an area of potential breeding habitat. This bird was within 5km of the above location, the precise location is withheld, at least for now, in case the bird is part of a breeding pair. Another recording of this bird can be found at XC564759.

Interestingly, as well as the more typical 'rattle' strophes, this bird also habitually threw in another song strophe type reminiscent of a Coal Tit, perhaps, and which could be dismissed as 'just a tit' if heard out of context from an unseen bird. Whether this is innate, and part of the normal 'vocabulary' of the species, or actual mimicry of a Coal Tit, I don't know.

Lesser Whitethroat is a scarce passage migrant in Ireland, mainly being found on headlands and islands, and is commoner in autumn than spring, though always a good find anywhere. Sporadic breeding records have been proven, and the incidence of singing birds in spring seems to be increasing, but, of course, the twin combination of low observer density and reduced effort away from the hotspots could lead to under-recording of the true picture. In this case, I may not have walked by the area in which the bird is holding territory were it not for travel restrictions due to COVID-19, and certainly wouldn't have found it had it not sang. It effectively didn't show at all when found on 30th May, bar for one flight view.

Notch filter applied below 250Hz, fade in and out applied also.

recordings.rmk:
Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 handheld on a glorious morning. The habitat here has mature but low scrub, allowed to develop in an area that is difficult to farm.  
EQ adjusted below 150 to remove faint background rumble and light handling noise.

recordings.loc: Ramscombe Bottom, Chilcombe, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Song given from bramble in an area that is difficult to farm and has been allowed to scrub up. You could call this the later stage of plastic song as the verses are not quite crystallised and still start with different explorations of sound. In particular, the verse at 1:31 does not finished with the typical sound of Lesser Whitethroat song.

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 handheld. EQ adjusted below 2000 Hz to reduce distant road noise. Deamplified slightly to reduce peak from around -3 dB to -6 dB.

recordings.loc: Sofue World Nature Park, Inazawa, Aichi
recordings.rmk:
Rarity.  The bird was not seen at the time of vocalization.
There were several Japanese bush warblers and the voice was
confusing.  The voice in this recording is lighter than
the Japanese bush warbler (less low frequency component
below 5 kHz) compared to the other recordings of
the Japanese bush warbler in the same place.
This recording also has a double note at 0:23 (such a double note
with a short interval is not heard in the Japanese bush warbler).
The voice is also similar to XC421581 and I gave this ID.
Only 1 min after this recording, the bird appeared and foraged.

An example of photos (not mine) on the web: https://blog.goo.ne.jp/mariko2502watanabe/e/742be16edcb2a2333ea8930f6923df8b

recordings.rmk: Two different type calls. last few phrases are different.

In this recording a Sylvia curruca sings subsong, similar to subsongs of other Sylvias like Sylvia atricapilla and Sylvia communis. The Sylvia curruca was followed from branch to branch at distances down to a metre by a quiet Sylvia atricapilla, clearly confused or upset by The Sylvia curruca's subsong. The Sylvia atricapilla had previously sung a subsong of its own.

Not only are the subsongs of Sylvias difficult to tell apart by birders, it seems even the Sylvias themselves have difficulties telling them apart!

Other recordings of the same Sylvia curruca singing subsong, which clearly demonstrates elements of mimicry have been uploaded as XC415773  and XC415772.

Two birds in a low Acacia. One fluffed up, scolding continually for over 3 mins. Both birds in very close proximity and not antagonistic to each other. There is some doubt as to which taxa of Lesser Whitethroat winters in Oman and the UAE in large numbers; they are currently believed to be, on the whole, halimodendri rather than (as was formerly thought) minula. This scolding call is the typical contact and agitation call used by birds wintering in this area and is a very common sound in the region from late September until March anywhere there are native trees or scrub.

recordings.loc: Trento, Provincia di Trento, Trentino-Alto Adige

recordings.rmk:
In this recording the Sylvia curruca sings subsong demonstrating mimicry. Mimicry in the subsongs of other Sylvias like Sylvia atricapilla and Sylvia communis is well known, but I don't know if it previously has been recorded and demonstrated in Sylvia curruca.

It mimicks Siskin (Spinus spinus) at 00:19.3, 00:11.4 and Chaffinch (Fringilla coelebs) at  00:13.9

Other recordings of the same Sylvia curruca singing subsong, have been uploaded as XC415772 and XC415763.

In this recording the Sylvia curruca sings subsong demonstrating mimicry. Mimicry in the subsongs of other Sylvias like Sylvia atricapilla and Sylvia communis is well known, but I don't know if it previously has been recorded and demonstrated in Sylvia curruca.

It mimicks Chaffinch (Fringilla coelebs) at 00:19.9 and Woodcock (Scolopax rusticola) at 01:02.5

Other recordings of the same Sylvia curruca singing subsong, have been uploaded as XC415773  and XC415763.

recordings.loc: Prague, Hlavní město Praha, Hlavní město Praha

recordings.rmk:
The bird rattled before caught with the mistnet. The  wing formula, DNA-analyzes and the calls proved this to be the first ssp. blythi in Finland. Accepted by the Finnish rarity committee: https://tiedostot.birdlife.fi/rk/RK-hyvaksytyt-2015-asti.pdf.

Some low traffic noise filtered out with the High Pass filter. Sec. 32 a different type call can be heard.

Amplified.

recordings.rmk: Probably same bird as XC373022, now perched on walnut tree. Field copse.
Field copse.
The rattle call is less common in the nominate curruca, but sometimes heard, especially in spring. Four birds were present very close to each other, and some of them are probably breeding there.
A rare bird in this area
A rare bird in this area
